docs.lead_paragraph: It is not just extensive habitat loss nor is it just poaching for its plush pelt that is doing in the giant panda. It is also evolution. Evolution simply has not done right by one of the world's most popular animals, now a critically endangered species with only about a thousand believed to exist in the wild. Start with the fact that female pandas, which live isolated from males in dense bamboo forests in China, have but two or three fertile days a year and must rely on chemical advertising across the thickets to attract an equally reclusive male. Then, if an egg is successfully fertilized, a 16-cell embryo just floats free in the womb for one to five months before it implants in the uterus and starts developing.

headline.main: With a Little Help From Friends, Pandas Hang On

docs.abstract: Scientists who collaborated on the birth of a panda at San Diego Zoo in August 1999 plan to use the experience and knowledged they gained to repeat their success once the mother panda stops nursing and begins ovulating again; researchers at zoo and in China are working to enhance pandas' physical and psychological health, foster their chemical communication and develop infant formulas more like natural panda milk; breeding program at Wolong Nature Preserve in Sichuan has had unprecedented success the last two years; photos; drawings (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mirrel Eissenberg, vice president of a real estate management firm, was wearing a floppy blue smock with teddy bears printed on it at the Maimonides Medical Center in Borough Park. When she is not making property deals, she is a hand holder, a massage giver and a calming voice for women undergoing childbirth.

headline.main: Orthodox Angels Are Aiding Women in Childbirth

docs.abstract: Article on work of group of 75 Orthodox Jewish women who volunteer at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, NY, as doulas, or labor coaches, for women giving birth; photo (M)
